author: f0rt
body:
Team,

**System**: Windows 10 + Anniversary update, PS 5.1.  

**Issue**: Install-Module cmdlets completes successfully but the installed module is not found after installation. After a short research I've found that the $env:PSModulePath variable doesn't contain the installation path (in this case "C:\Users\<username>\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules").  The variable $env:PSModulePath is not modified by the user. Adding the path to $env:PSModulePath resolves the issue. Let me know if you need more information.

Thanks,
Nedko

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
@f0rt This looks like a problem with your `PSModulePath` rather than PowerShellGet. 

The default state of `PSModulePath` is for the system variable to point to `%SystemRoot%\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\`, and the user variable should not exist. At runtime, we prepend `$env:PSModulePath` with `C:\Users<username>\Documents\WindowsPowerShell\Modules;C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules`. 

If that's not happening on your end, I'd really appreciate some more info on:
* how you're launching PowerShell (is it from a shortcut on the taskbar or the start menu? Or is it from the Start->Run/Win+R?) 
* What your system and user environment variables for PSModulePath look like, preferably from the System GUI, e.g. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1255187/24052989/b112d6d2-0af4-11e7-9180-cd276c94212b.png)

comments.author: bdwakefield
comments.body:
> My standing workaround is `$env:PSModulePath += ";C:\Users\$($env:UserName)\Documents\PowerShell\Modules"`.

Added this to my profile; works like a charm. Fought with this for over an hour. Couldn't figure out why the modules would install but not import.
